senses.definition: an informal shirt, usually with short sleeves (= arms) no collar or buttons, or just a few buttons at the top
examples: He was wearing a faded pair of blue jeans and an old T-shirt.
a sleeveless/long-sleeved T-shirt

senses.definition: a piece of furniture that consists of a flat top supported by legs
examples: at a/the table We sat at a round table in the corner.
around/round a/the table They were sitting around the kitchen table.
She took a seat at the end of the table.
My father always sits at the head of the table.
A table for two, please (= in a restaurant).
I'd like to book a table for dinner tonight (= in a restaurant)
to set the table
(British English also) to lay the table (= to put the plates, knives, etc. on it for a meal)
to clear the table (= take away the dirty plates, etc. at the end of a meal)
He questioned her next morning over the breakfast table (= during breakfast).
a pool/billiard/snooker table
He left the table in a hurry.
James crawled out from under the table.
She leaned across the table and kissed him.
They flirted over the dinner table.
We found an empty table at the back of the restaurant.
We gathered around the table to hear his news.
We turned the box upside down and used it as a makeshift table.
We'll take the corner table near the bar, please.

senses.definition: the people sitting at a table for a meal or to play cards, etc.
examples: He kept the whole table entertained with his jokes.

senses.definition: a list of facts or numbers arranged in a special order, usually in rows and columns
examples: a table of contents (= a list of the main points or information in a book, usually at the front of the book)
The table below shows how prices have changed over the past 20 years.
in a/the table He showed the price fluctuations in a statistical table.
See Table XII for population figures.

senses.definition: a list of sports teams, countries, schools, etc. that shows their position in a competition, etc.
examples: If Arsenal win this game they'll go to the top of the table.
the bottom of the table
in a/the table United are second in the table.
The team will be lucky to finish the season mid-table.

senses.definition: a list showing the results when a number is multiplied by a set of other numbers, especially 1 to 12, in turn
examples: Do you know your six times table?

senses.definition: to contribute something useful to a discussion, project, etc.
examples: What Hislop brought to the table was real commitment and energy.

senses.definition: to join formal discussions about something
examples: Different countries come to the table with differing expectations about what they can achieve.

senses.definition: to drink more alcohol than somebody else without becoming as drunk as they are
to tell somebody honestly what your plans, ideas, etc. are
if a topic is off the table at a formal discussion, people are not willing or allowed to discuss it
examples: Some issues were so controversial they were taken off the table.

senses.definition: offered to people so that they can consider or discuss it
examples: Management have put several new proposals on the table.

senses.definition: not going to be discussed or considered until a future date
to change a situation so that you are now in a stronger position than the person who used to be in a stronger position than you
to serve food to people, for example at a formal meal
to work serving food to people in a restaurant
a small computer that is easy to carry, with a large touch screen and usually without a physical keyboard
examples: The company has launched its latest 10-inch tablet.
Consumers show a growing preference for tablets and smartphones over PCs and laptops.

senses.definition: a small round solid piece of medicine that you swallow
examples: Take two tablets with water before meals.
I took the tablets prescribed by my doctor.
The drug is now available in tablet and capsule form.

senses.definition: an amount of a substance in a small, round, solid piece
examples: water purification tablets

senses.definition: a flat piece of stone that has words written on it, especially one that has been fixed to a wall in memory of an important person or event
examples: The school has a memorial tablet engraved with the name of the founder.
(figurative) We can be very flexible—our entry requirements are not set in tablets of stone (= they can be changed).

senses.definition: a piece of soap
a number of pieces of paper for writing or drawing on, that are fastened together at one edge
the part that sticks out at the back of the body of a bird, an animal or a fish, which the animal can move from side to side or up and down
examples: The dog ran up, wagging its tail.
My dog loves to chase his tail.
The male has beautiful tail feathers.
It was black from its nose to the tip of its tail.
The peacock fans out its magnificent tail to attract females.
A spy is sent to tail the family and find out everything they do.
She told the children the tale of the tortoise and the hare.

senses.definition: having the type of tail mentioned
examples: a white-tailed eagle

senses.definition: the back part of a plane, spacecraft, etc.
examples: The plane's tail section had broken off.

senses.definition: a part of something that sticks out at the back like a tail
examples: the tail of a kite

senses.definition: the last part of something that is moving away from you
examples: the tail of the procession
the truck at the tail of our convoy

senses.definition: a long jacket divided at the back below the waist into two pieces that become narrower at the bottom, worn by men at very formal events
examples: The men all wore top hat and tails.

senses.definition: the side of a coin that does not have a picture of the head of a person on it, used as one choice when a coin is tossed to decide something
a person who is sent to follow somebody secretly and find out information about where that person goes, what they do, etc.
examples: The police have put a tail on him.

senses.definition: to be unable to understand something
examples: I couldn't make head nor tail of what he was saying.

senses.definition: to be very busy but in fact achieve very little
used to ask somebody which side of a coin they think will be facing upwards when it is tossed in order to decide something by chance
if cars, etc. are nose to tail, they are moving slowly in a long line with little space between them
examples: The traffic was nose to tail for miles.

senses.definition: following behind somebody very closely, especially in a car
examples: There’s been a white van sitting on my tail for the past ten miles.

senses.definition: an unpleasant feature that comes at the end of a story, an event, etc. and makes it less good, successful, etc.
used to describe a situation in which the most important aspect is being influenced and controlled by somebody/something that is not as important
to run away from a fight or dangerous situation
examples: When they heard the sirens, they turned tail and ran.

senses.definition: feeling ashamed or unhappy because you have been defeated or punished
to carry or move something from one place to another
examples: take something Remember to take your coat when you leave.
take something with you I forgot to take my bag with me when I got off the bus.
take somebody something Shall I take my host family a gift?
take something to somebody/something Can you take my suit to the dry-cleaner's?
You need to take your laptop to the technician.
take something for somebody/something Don't forget to take a present for Catherine's new baby.
My things had already been taken to my room.
She took her bags along with her.
Think about what you need to take for the trip.

senses.definition: to go with somebody from one place to another, especially to guide or lead them
examples: take somebody It's too far to walk—I'll take you by car.
take somebody to something A boy took us to our room.
take somebody doing something I'm taking the kids swimming later.
take somebody to do something The boys were taken to see their grandparents most weekends.
It’s too far to walk—I’ll take you by car.
Firefighters led the survivors to safety.
The President arrived, escorted by twelve bodyguards.
My mother drove us to the airport.
The attendant showed us to our seats.
He always walked her home.
Have you walked the dog yet today?
She guided us through the busy streets.
We were guided around the museums.
She ushered her guests to their seats.
A young woman directed them to the station.
You should take her home soon.
I asked them if they'd take me with them.

senses.definition: to make somebody/something go from one level, situation, etc. to another
examples: Her energy and talent took her to the top of her profession.
The new loan takes the total debt to $100 000.
I'd like to take my argument a stage further.
He believes he has the skills to take the club forward.
We'll take the matter forward at our next meeting (= discuss it further).

senses.definition: to need or require a particular amount of time
examples: take something The process took about a year.
The journey to the airport takes about half an hour.
take something to do something It takes about half an hour to get to the airport.
That cut is taking a long time to heal.
The official seemed to take hours to examine my passport.
take somebody something That should only take you ten minutes.
take somebody something to do something It took her three hours to repair her bike.
It'll take her time to recover from the illness.
take something for somebody to do something It'll take time (= take a long time) for her to recover from the illness.
+ adv. I need a shower—I won't take long.
How long do you think this storm will last?
The movie lasted over two hours.
His annoyance won’t last.
The money she gave us should last until next week.
It takes (me) at least an hour to get home from work.
How long will the flight take?
The water took ages to boil.

senses.definition: to photograph somebody/something
examples: take something to take a picture/photo/shot of somebody/something
to have your picture/photo taken

senses.definition: to use a form of transport, a road, a path, etc. to go to a place
examples: to take the bus/train
to take a cab/plane
Take the second road on the right.
It's more interesting to take the coast road.
You'll have to take a taxi. There's no other way of getting there.
You fly to Brussels and take the train to Bruges.
We took a ferry across to the island.
We took a bus south to Cairo.
They took the night train to Vienna.

senses.definition: to put your hands or arms around somebody/something and hold them/it; to reach for somebody/something and hold them/it
examples: I passed him the rope and he took it.
Free newspapers: please take one.
Can you take (= hold) the baby for a moment?
He took her hand/took her by the hand (= held her hand, for example to lead her somewhere).
She took the child in her arms and kissed him.

senses.definition: to remove something/somebody from a place or a person
examples: Will you take your books off the table?
The sign must be taken down.
He took some keys out of his pocket.
My name had been taken off the list.
She was playing with a knife, so I took it away from her.
(informal) She was playing with a knife, so I took it off her.
(figurative) The new sports centre will take the pressure off the old one.

senses.definition: to remove something without permission or by mistake
examples: Someone has taken my scarf.
Did the burglars take anything valuable?
All she had taken was her passport and driving licence.
(figurative) The storms took the lives of 50 people.

senses.definition: to get something from a particular source
examples: take something from something The scientists are taking water samples from the river.
The machine takes its name from its inventor.
take something out of something Part of her article is taken straight (= copied) out of my book.

senses.definition: to sit down in or use a chair, etc.
examples: Are these seats taken?
Come in; take a seat.
May I sit here?
Sit still, will you!
Please sit down.
Come in and sit yourselves down.
She was seated at the head of the table.
She perched herself on the edge of the bed.

senses.definition: to eat, drink, etc. something
examples: Do you take sugar in your coffee?
The doctor has given me some medicine to take for my cough.
He started taking drugs (= illegal drugs) at college.

senses.definition: to find out and record something; to write something down
examples: The police officer took my name and address.
Did you take notes in the class?

senses.definition: to do an exam or a test
examples: When did you take your driving test?

senses.definition: to study a subject at school, college, etc.
examples: She is planning to take a course in web design.
Last year I started taking yoga classes.
How many subjects are you taking this year?

senses.definition: to use a particular course of action in order to deal with or achieve something
examples: take something We need to take a different approach to the problem.
The government is taking action to combat drug abuse.

senses.definition: used with nouns to say that somebody is doing something, performing an action, etc.
examples: to take a look
to take a break
to take a shot at somebody/something
to take a step/walk/stroll
to take a bath/shower/wash
to take a bite/drink/sip
to take a deep breath
(British English) We will take a decision on the matter next week.
She's taken a nasty fall and has her leg in plaster.
Experts have urged ministers to take the necessary steps to resolve the issue.

senses.definition: to test or measure something
examples: to take somebody’s temperature
I need to have my blood pressure taken.

senses.definition: to capture a place or person; to get control of something
examples: take something The rebels succeeded in taking the town.
The state has taken control of the company.
take something from somebody The militants took the city from government forces.
take somebody + noun The rebels took him prisoner.
He was taken prisoner by the rebels.
The bank robbers took several employees hostage.

senses.definition: to choose, buy or rent something
examples: I'll take the grey jacket.
We took a room at the hotel for two nights.

senses.definition: to buy a newspaper or magazine regularly
examples: We take the ‘Express’.

senses.definition: to accept or receive something
examples: If they offer me the job, I'll take it.
She was accused of taking bribes.
I'll take the call in my office.
I take full responsibility for my actions.
Why should I take the blame for somebody else's mistakes?
If you choose deceit, then you must take the consequences of your actions.
If you take my advice you'll have nothing more to do with him.
Will you take $10 for the book (= will you sell it for $10)?
The store took (= sold goods worth) $100 000 last week.

senses.definition: to act in response to an opportunity
examples: When the bus stopped for fuel, we took the opportunity to get something to eat.
England failed to take their chances and had to settle for a draw.
He isn't afraid to take risks.
Take the initiative and fill your life with exciting experiences.

senses.definition: to accept somebody as a customer, patient, etc.
examples: The school doesn't take boys (= only has girls).
The dentist can't take any new patients.

senses.definition: to experience or be affected by something
examples: The school took the full force of the explosion.
Can the ropes take the strain (= not break)?
The team took a terrible beating.
I'm afraid your husband has taken a turn for the worse.

senses.definition: to be able to bear something
examples: She can't take criticism.
I don't think I can take much more of this heat.
I find his attitude a little hard to take.
It was clear that she wasn't going to take any nonsense.

senses.definition: to react to something/somebody in a particular way
examples: He took the criticism surprisingly well.
These threats are not to be taken lightly.
I wish you'd take me seriously.
I was being sarcastic but you took my comment literally.
She took it in the spirit in which it was intended.
Harry took his rejection philosophically.
She took the news of her father's death very badly.
I wanted to be taken seriously as an artist.
They won't take kindly to being ordered about.

senses.definition: to understand or consider something in a particular way
examples: take something How am I supposed to take that remark?
Taken overall, the project was a success.
take something as something She took what he said as a compliment.
take something to do something What did you take his comments to mean?

senses.definition: to consider somebody/something to be somebody/something, especially when you are wrong
examples: take somebody/something for somebody/something Even the experts took the painting for a genuine Van Gogh.
Of course I didn't do it! What do you take me for (= what sort of person do you think I am)?
take somebody/something to be somebody/something I took the man with him to be his father.
I mistakenly took her for the Senator's wife.
He's not the fool you take him for.

senses.definition: to have a particular feeling, opinion or attitude
examples: My parents always took an interest in my hobbies.
Don't take offence (= be offended) at what I said.
I took a dislike to him.
He takes the view that children are responsible for their own actions.

senses.definition: to reduce one number by the value of another
examples: take A (away) (from B) Take 5 from 12 and you're left with 7.
B take away A (informal) 80 take away 5 is 75.

senses.definition: used to introduce somebody/something as an example
examples: Lots of couples have problems in the first year of marriage. Take Ann and Paul.

senses.definition: to have or start to have a particular form, position or state
examples: Our next class will take the form of a debate.
The new president takes office in January.
The home side had a chance to take the lead.

senses.definition: to need or require something in order to happen or be done
examples: take somebody/something to do something It only takes one careless driver to cause an accident.
It doesn't take much to make her angry.
take something (informal) He didn't take much persuading (= he was easily persuaded).

senses.definition: to use something in order to work
examples: The buses have been adapted to take biofuel.

senses.definition: to wear a particular size in shoes or clothes
examples: What size shoes do you take?

senses.definition: to have enough space for something/somebody; to be able to hold or contain a particular quantity
examples: The bus can take 60 passengers.
The tank takes 50 litres.

senses.definition: to be the teacher or leader in a class or a religious service
examples: take somebody (for something) The head teacher usually takes us for French.
take something Mr Perkins took the morning service.

senses.definition: to go over or around something
examples: The horse took the first fence well.
He takes bends much too fast.

senses.definition: to kick or throw the ball from a fixed or agreed position
examples: to take a penalty/free kick/corner

senses.definition: to use a particular method to find out people’s opinions
examples: to take a vote/poll/survey

senses.definition: to be successful; to work
examples: The skin graft failed to take.

senses.definition: to have or require something when used in a sentence or other structure
examples: The verb ‘rely’ takes the preposition ‘on’.

senses.definition: used to say that you do not care if somebody accepts or rejects your offer
used to say that somebody does not have a strong opinion about something
examples: Dancing? I can take it or leave it.

senses.definition: to have the qualities, ability, etc. needed to be successful
used to say that you cannot trust somebody to behave well in public
examples: You haven’t spilled your coffee again! I can’t take you anywhere!

senses.definition: to accept something/somebody without wishing it/them to be different or without thinking about it/them very much in advance
examples: She takes life as it comes.

senses.definition: to suppose; to assume
examples: I take it you won't be coming to the party?

senses.definition: used to emphasize that what you are going to say is the truth
examples: Take it from me—he'll be a millionaire before he's 30.

senses.definition: to make somebody physically or mentally tired
examples: Looking after small children really takes it out of you.

senses.definition: to decide to do something without asking permission or advice
to need a lot of effort or time; to be very difficult to do
used as an exclamation when you are hitting somebody or attacking them in some other way
a story created using the imagination, especially one that is full of action and adventure
examples: a coming-of-age/morality tale
tale of something The story is a classic tale of love and betrayal.
Dickens’ ‘A Tale of Two Cities’
His latest book is a delightful children’s tale about talking animals.
The peacock fans out its magnificent tail to attract females.
A spy is sent to tail the family and find out everything they do.
She told the children the tale of the tortoise and the hare.
It's a moral tale about a baker and a shoemaker.
a dark tale of sexual obsession
a tale about a hungry snake
a tale set in 19th-century Moscow
an epic tale of courage and heroism
tales of adventure
the curious tale of the man who sold his hair
the rags-to-riches tale of an orphan who becomes a star

senses.definition: an exciting spoken description of an event, which may not be completely true
examples: I love listening to his tales of life at sea.
I've heard tales of people seeing ghosts in that house.
She regaled us with tales of her wild youth.
The team's tale of woe continued on Saturday (= they lost another match).
Her experiences provide a cautionary tale (= a warning) for us all.
She was tired of hearing the same dreary tale of drunkenness and violence.
the sorry tale of his marriage breakdown

senses.definition: to survive a difficult or dangerous experience so that you can tell others what really happened
an old idea or belief that people now know is not correct
to give some information that is different from what you expect or have been told
examples: These drugs are widely believed to be effective medications. The data, however, tell a different story.

senses.definition: to explain itself, without needing any further explanation or comment
examples: Her face told its own story.

senses.definition: to tell somebody about something that another person has done wrong
a natural ability to do something well
examples: The festival showcases the talent of young musicians.
to possess/have exceptional musical talent
The team is known for nurturing raw talent.
a man of many talents
talent for (doing) something She displayed her talent for comedy at the event.
She showed considerable talent for getting what she wanted.
a talent contest/competition (= in which people perform, to show how well they can sing, dance, etc.)
to have great artistic talent
Hard work is important, but it is no substitute for talent.
He is a violinist of exceptional talent.
Her talents lay in organization.
His parents accused him of wasting his talents and abilities.
It takes real talent to write a great pop song.
The banquet gave the chef a chance to flaunt his talents.
Where does her musical talent come from?
You have a natural talent for storytelling.
an effort to develop his creative talents to the full

senses.definition: people or a person with a natural ability to do something well
examples: to nurture/develop young talent
We are losing our top talent to other countries who pay more.
He is a great talent.
There is a wealth of young talent in British theatre.
Hollywood directors have a marvellous pool of acting talent to draw from.
The company is always looking out for new talent.
The festival attracts talent from all over the world.
There is a shortage of new comedy talent coming through.
United have unearthed a real talent in this young defender.
one of the few teams that relies on home-grown talent

senses.definition: people who are sexually attractive
examples: He likes to spend his time chatting up the local talent.

senses.definition: having a natural ability to do something well
examples: a talented player/musician/artist
Some of these young musicians are incredibly talented.
She's an extremely talented singer.
The kids at this school are all exceptionally talented in some way.
We're looking for talented young designers to join our team.

senses.definition: a speech or lecture on a particular subject
examples: I went to several interesting talks at the conference.
talk on something She gave a talk on her visit to China.
talk about something I heard a talk about the history of printing.
Several people made speeches at the wedding.
a lecture on the Roman army
a course/​series of lectures
a televised presidential address
She gave an interesting talk on her visit to China.
to preach a sermon
I found the sales talk very persuasive.
She gave an illustrated talk on Roman architecture.
Let me end my talk with a prediction.
Did you go to the talk on Peru?

senses.definition: a conversation or discussion
examples: She looked worried so we had a talk.
talk about something We need to have a serious talk about money matters.
talk with somebody I had to have a heart-to-heart talk with her.
I will have to have a little talk with that young lady (= talk to her about something she has done wrong).
talk with somebody about something I had a long talk with my boss about my career prospects.
Discussions are still taking place between the two leaders.
a telephone conversation
The novel has long descriptions and not much dialogue.
The President told waiting reporters there had been a constructive dialogue.
I had a long talk with my boss about my career prospects.
a debate on prison reform
There have been extensive consultations between the two countries.
We had a good gossip about the boss.
I enjoyed our talk about the old days.
Every week the sales reps go to their manager's office for a team talk.

senses.definition: formal discussions between governments or organizations
examples: peace/trade talks
to hold talks
to engage in/enter into talks
to pull out of talks
talks with somebody/something The delegation arrived for talks with their government.
in talks with somebody/something He is currently in talks with two football clubs.
talks between A and B Talks between management and workers broke down over the issue of holiday pay.
talks on something Leaders will resume talks on the trade deal next month.
talks over something Talks continue over the political future of the province.
A further round of talks will be needed if the dispute is to be resolved.
Union representatives walked out of emergency talks aimed at reaching a pay settlement.
Talks produced agreement on an end to the occupation.
The peace talks will take place in Cairo.
The talks centred on bilateral trade.
The talks foundered on the issue of compensation.
The two governments held secret talks on the nuclear threat.
The talks remain deadlocked over spending plans.

senses.definition: words that are spoken, but without the necessary facts or actions to support them
examples: It's just talk. He'd never carry out his threats.
Don't pay any attention to her—she's all talk.
For all their talk of equality, the boys ended up not doing any cooking.
The chairman's boasts about future profits was just cheap talk.
What all the fine talk came down to was hard cash.

senses.definition: stories that suggest a particular thing might be true or might happen in the future
examples: She dismissed the stories of her resignation as newspaper talk.
talk of (doing) something There was talk in Washington of sending in troops.
talk that… There’s talk that he’s a difficult actor to work with.
All this talk of the boss resigning is nonsense!
There is ridiculous talk of her breaking the world record soon.
There was excited talk of emigrating to America.
You often hear talk of the north-south divide.
There is open talk of a leadership challenge.
There has been much public talk about bilingual education.

senses.definition: a topic of conversation or a way of speaking
examples: business talk
She said it was just girl talk that a man wouldn't understand.
The book teaches you how to understand Spanish street talk (= slang).
It was tough talk, coming from a man who had begun the year in a hospital bed.
She likes straight talk and hates hypocrites.
The president's true agenda was hidden in political double talk.
The US authorities have increased the war talk.
the crusade against dirty talk on TV
the pillow talk of lovers
Talk turned to money and tempers began to fray.

senses.definition: comments or remarks that show that you are ready to fight very hard for something
examples: What we want from the management is fighting talk.

senses.definition: the person or thing that everyone is talking about in a particular place
examples: Overnight, she became the talk of the town (= very famous).

senses.definition: to say things; to speak in order to give information or to express ideas or feelings
examples: Stop talking and listen!
We talked on the phone for over an hour.
talk to somebody Who were you talking to just now?
Ann and Joe aren't talking to each other right now (= they refuse to speak to each other because they have argued).
talk to yourself Watch the scene where Don talks to himself in the mirror while shaving.
talk with somebody We looked around the school and talked with the principal.
talk about somebody/something They talk a lot about the inspiration for their music.
When they get together, all they talk about is football.
What are you talking about? (= used when you are surprised, annoyed and/or worried by something that somebody has just said)
I don't know what you're talking about (= used to say that you did not do something that somebody has accused you of).
to talk openly/freely/publicly about something
talk to/with somebody about somebody/something She started talking loudly to her friends about the film they'd just seen.
talk of doing something Mary is talking of looking for another job.
talk of something We often talked of the war.
talk yourself + adj. We talked ourselves hoarse, catching up on all the news.
He was so easy to talk to.
I think you'd better talk directly to my manager.
I'll talk to John this afternoon.
I can't talk about it just now.
Bruce Springsteen has agreed to talk exclusively to our reporter about his life.
I loved to hear him talk about the old days.
She talked quite freely about her work.
He had talked vaguely of going to work abroad.
He talked excitedly of his plans.

senses.definition: to discuss something, usually something serious or important
examples: This situation can't go on. We need to talk.
The two sides in the dispute are finally willing to talk.
talk to/with somebody Talk with your doctor before radically changing your diet.
talk about something Is there anything you'd like to talk about?
talk to/with somebody about something We want to talk to people about this issue.
talk something to talk politics
We talked on the phone for over an hour.
Have you discussed the problem with anyone?
I’ve spoken to the manager about it.
‘Can I speak to Susan?’ ‘Speaking.’ (= at the beginning of a phone conversation)
We only communicate by email.
Dolphins use sound to communicate with each other.
Politicians will be debating the bill later this week.
You shouldn’t have done it without consulting me.

senses.definition: to say words in a language
examples: The baby is just starting to talk.
Alex can't talk yet—he's only just one year old.
talk in something We couldn't understand them because they were talking in Chinese.
talk something Are they talking Swedish or Danish?

senses.definition: to say things that are/are not sensible
examples: She talks a lot of sense.
(British English) You're talking rubbish!
See if you can talk some sense into him (= persuade him to be sensible).

senses.definition: used to emphasize an amount of money, how serious something is, etc.
examples: We're talking £500 for three hours' work.
Do you know what this will cost? We’re talking megabucks here.

senses.definition: to talk about a person’s private life
examples: Don't phone me at work—people will talk.

senses.definition: to give information to somebody, especially unwillingly
examples: The police questioned him but he refused to talk.

senses.definition: to try and persuade somebody to stop behaving in a stupid way, sometimes using rough or violent methods

This diagram shows how paper is made.
First/First of all, logs are delivered to a paper mill, where the bark is removed and the wood is cut into small chips.
Next/Second, the wood chips are pulped, either using chemicals or in a pulping machine.
Pulping breaks down the internal structure of the wood and enables/allows the natural oils to be removed.
Once/After the wood has been pulped, the pulp is bleached in order to remove impurities. /…is bleached so that impurities can be removed.
The next stage is to feed the pulp into the paper machine, where it is mixed with water and then poured onto a wire conveyor belt.
As the pulp travels along the conveyor belt, the water drains away. This causes the solid material to sink to the bottom, forming a layer of paper.
At this point the new paper is still wet, so it is passed between large heated rollers, which press out the remaining water and simultaneously dry the paper/…dry the paper at the same time.

examples: in time to something Try and dance in time to the music (= with the same speed and rhythm).

in/out of time to play in/out of time (= follow/not follow the correct speed and rhythm)
He always plays in perfect time.

senses.definition: used to say that something should have happened before now
if you do something against time, you do it as fast as you can because you do not have much time
examples: They're working against time to try and get people out of the rubble alive.

senses.definition: earlier/later than was expected
examples: We finished 15 minutes ahead of time.
The plane took off an hour behind time.

senses.definition: having advanced or new ideas that other people use or copy later
during the whole of a particular period of time
examples: The letter was in my pocket all the time (= while I was looking for it).

senses.definition: very often; repeatedly
examples: She leaves the lights on all the time.

senses.definition: always
examples: Our representatives are ready to help you at all times.
Hot water is available at all times.

senses.definition: even when the circumstances are very good
examples: He's never very happy at the best of times—he'll be much worse now!

senses.definition: at one time; together
examples: She was laughing and crying at the same time.

senses.definition: used to introduce a fact that is different and must be considered
examples: You have to be firm, but at the same time you should try and be sympathetic.

senses.definition: separately or in groups of two, three, etc. on each occasion
examples: We had to go and see the principal one at a time.
She ran up the stairs two at a time.
He surfs the internet for hours at a time.

senses.definition: at the age you are (especially when you are not young)
examples: Eyesight doesn't get any better at my time of life.

senses.definition: sometimes
examples: He can be really bad-tempered at times.
The rain will become heavy at times in the afternoon.
He can be rather moody at times.

senses.definition: to mark or follow the rhythm of music, by waving a stick, tapping your foot (= hitting it against the floor), etc.
examples: She beat time with her fingers.

senses.definition: happening before you were born or can remember or before you lived, worked, etc. somewhere
examples: ‘Were you taught by Professor Pascal?’ ‘No, he was before my time.’

senses.definition: before the usual time in somebody’s life when something happens
examples: She got old before her time.

senses.definition: old-fashioned in your ideas, methods, etc.
to be able to take advantage of opportunities when they come
examples: His success was down to being in the right place at the right time.

senses.definition: to still be alive after the time when you were expected to die
examples: He’s been living on borrowed time ever since his last heart attack.

senses.definition: to be doing something that other people are likely to soon stop you from doing
examples: According to the latest opinion polls, the government is living on borrowed time.

senses.definition: used to encourage somebody who has not been successful at something
examples: Never mind— better luck next time.
If you didn't win a prize, better luck next time.

senses.definition: to wait for the right time to do something
examples: He decided to bide his time until he got an opportunity to talk to her alone.

senses.definition: to do something in order to delay an event, a decision, etc.
examples: The negotiators kept the gunman talking to buy time for the hostages.

senses.definition: to say or decide that it is time for something to finish
a very difficult or unpleasant job or time
examples: I've had a devil of a job finding you.

senses.definition: to spend time in prison
whenever there is a choice
examples: I don't really like cities—give me the countryside every time.

senses.definition: if you do something for old times’ sake, you do it because it is connected with something good that happened to you in the past
for a short period of time but not permanently
examples: You can leave your suitcase here for the time being.

senses.definition: beginning on that day; from that time
examples: From that time forth she gave me endless friendship and encouragement.

senses.definition: occasionally but not regularly
examples: She has to work at weekends from time to time.

senses.definition: to delay something so that you can have more time to make a decision, deal with a problem, etc.
to deliberately make a situation difficult and unpleasant for somebody
examples: They really gave me a hard time at the interview.

senses.definition: used to say that you prefer a particular thing or person to the one that has just been mentioned
examples: We don't go out much. Give me a quiet night in front of the TV any day!

senses.definition: to have no difficulties or problems
examples: He’s had an easy time of it since he married Lucy.

senses.definition: to enjoy yourself very much
to like and be interested in somebody/something
examples: I've always had a lot of time for Mary.

senses.definition: to dislike somebody/something
examples: I have no time for lazy people like Steve.

senses.definition: to have many problems or difficulties to deal with; to not be successful
examples: He’s had a thin time of it since losing his job.

senses.definition: to enjoy yourself very much
to have nothing to do or not be busy
to enjoy yourself very much; to have a very good time
examples: The kids had a whale of a time at the theme park.

senses.definition: when enough time has passed
examples: It is possible that in the course of time a cure for cancer will be found.
In the course of time, I began to understand.

senses.definition: when the time is appropriate, usually after a long period
examples: I have no doubt that she’ll tell us in the fullness of time.

senses.definition: early; with enough time so that you are not in a hurry
examples: Get to the airport in good time.

senses.definition: used to say that something will be done or will happen at the appropriate time and not before
examples: Be patient, Emily! All in good time.

senses.definition: at the very last moment; just before something bad happens, so that you manage to avoid it, but only just
examples: They escaped from the smoke-filled house just in the nick of time.

senses.definition: so soon or so quickly that it is surprising
examples: The kids will be leaving home in no time.

senses.definition: a long time ago in the past
examples: In olden times people would gather in town squares to gossip and exchange stories.

senses.definition: how and when you want to, even though this might annoy other people
examples: He always does the work, but in his own sweet time.
She just ignores all the criticism and continues in her own sweet way.

senses.definition: when you are ready and not sooner
examples: Don't hassle him! He'll do it in his own good time.

senses.definition: in your free time and not when you usually work or study
after a period of time when a situation has changed
examples: They learned to accept their stepmother in time.
You'll get used to the work in time.

senses.definition: not late; with enough time to be able to do something
examples: Will we be in time for the six o'clock train?
The ambulance got there just in time (= to save somebody's life).

senses.definition: used to say that you think somebody should do something soon
examples: It's about time you cleaned your room!

senses.definition: used to say that something will definitely happen, although you are not sure when
examples: It's only a matter of time before they bring out their own version of the software.

senses.definition: to change and develop your ideas, way of working, etc. so that you do what is modern and what is expected
examples: Many complained that the Royal Family had failed to move with the times.

senses.definition: to spend time doing something that is not important while you are waiting for something else to happen
examples: We killed time playing cards.

senses.definition: used to say hello to somebody you have not seen for a long time
to complete a journey quickly
examples: We made excellent time and arrived in Spain in two days.

senses.definition: to do something quickly or very often because you wish you had started doing it sooner
examples: I’ll have to work hard now to make up for lost time.

senses.definition: many times; frequently
to pass the time while you wait for something more interesting
examples: I'm just marking time in this job—I'm hoping to get into journalism.

senses.definition: to make marching movements without moving forwards
on the next, first, etc. occasion that the same thing happens
examples: He repeated none of the errors he'd made first time round.
This time round it was not so easy.

senses.definition: used to say that something is usually true or almost always happens
examples: Nine times out of ten she gives the right answer.

senses.definition: almost always
used to say that something should have happened before now
to refuse to speak to somebody because you do not like or respect them
examples: Since the success of her novel, people shake her hand who once wouldn't have given her the time of day.

senses.definition: now is the best time to do something, not in the future
that has ever existed
examples: Many rated him the best singer of all time.

senses.definition: used, especially at the beginning of stories, to mean ‘a long time ago in the past’
examples: Once upon a time there was a beautiful princess.

senses.definition: at the arranged or correct time; not late
examples: The train arrived right on time.

senses.definition: to say hello to somebody and have a short conversation with them
to find or create reasons why something has to be delayed, often so you have longer to prepare for it
examples: His legal team, clearly playing for time, sought to have the case heard a month later.

senses.definition: a situation in which you have to do something or finish something very fast before it is too late
examples: Getting food to the starving refugees is now a race against time.

senses.definition: something that you feel shows what things are like now, especially how bad they are
examples: The increasing number of people owning guns is an alarming sign of the times.

senses.definition: it is better to deal with something immediately because if you wait it may become worse or more difficult and cause extra work
to not think about what will happen in the future
examples: I don't know if he'll get better. We're just taking it one day at a time.

senses.definition: to use as much time as you need without hurrying
examples: There's no rush—take your time.

senses.definition: used to say you think somebody is late or is too slow in doing something
examples: You certainly took your time getting here!

senses.definition: to spend some time away from your usual work or activity in order to rest or do something else instead
examples: She is taking time out from her music career for a year.
We stopped for a well-earned rest.
Let’s take a break.
The drug brought a brief respite from the pain.
Take time out to relax by the pool.
This delay gives the party a breathing space in which to sort out its policies.

senses.definition: the fact that something has not happened before does not mean that it will never happen
used when you have failed to do something twice and hope that you will succeed the third time
often; on many or all occasions
examples: You will get a perfect result time after time if you follow these instructions.
Time and again, the girls have shown how strong and determined they can be.

senses.definition: one and a half times the usual rate of pay
examples: We get time and a half on Sundays.

senses.definition: time seems to pass very quickly
examples: How time flies! I've got to go now.
Time has flown since the holiday began.

senses.definition: time is valuable, and should not be wasted
used to say that somebody can wait for something to happen or can wait before doing something
used to say that something used to happen in the past
examples: Time was when you could go for a walk in the country and not see another person for miles.
Time was when we never needed to lock our house at night.

senses.definition: used to say that you will have to wait for some time to find out the result of a situation
examples: Only time will tell if the treatment has been successful.

senses.definition: during the whole of a particular period of time
examples: My keys were in my pocket the whole time (= while I was looking for them).

senses.definition: very often; repeatedly
examples: He drums his fingers on the table the whole time—it's very annoying.

senses.definition: to measure how long it takes for something to happen or for somebody to do something
examples: time something ‘How long does it take to get to Leeds from here?’ ‘I don’t know, I’ve never timed it.’
time something at something The winner was timed at 20.4 seconds.
time how long… Time how long it takes you to run ten laps.
Time how long it takes you to answer the questions.

senses.definition: to arrange to do something or arrange for something to happen at a particular time
examples: time something for something She timed her arrival for shortly after 3.
be… timed Their visit was perfectly timed.
The runners set off at precisely timed intervals.
Their request was poorly timed (= it was made at the wrong time).
time something + adv. If we time it right, we should miss the traffic.
‘I hope we're not too early.’ ‘You couldn't have timed it better!’
be timed to do something The announcement of her new role was timed to coincide with the launch of her latest book.
The meeting is timed for 2 o'clock.
The schedule must be carefully timed.
This campaign is well timed.
a beautifully timed entrance
The show is timed to coincide with the launch of her new book.

senses.definition: to hit or kick a ball at a particular moment in a sports game
examples: She timed the pass perfectly.
a beautifully timed shot

senses.definition: a metal container in which food is sold; the contents of one of these containers
examples: Open the tin and drain the tuna.
tin of something a tin of beans/soup
Next, add two tins of tomatoes.
a sardine tin

senses.definition: a metal container with a lid (= cover), in the shape of a cylinder, in which paint, glue, etc. is sold and stored; the contents of one of these containers
examples: tin of something a tin of varnish
The bedroom needed three tins of paint (= in order to paint it).
a paint tin

senses.definition: a metal container with a lid (= cover) used for keeping food in
examples: a biscuit/cake/cookie tin
Store the seeds in an airtight tin.

senses.definition: a metal container used for cooking food in
examples: a cake/loaf tin

senses.definition: a chemical element. Tin is a soft silver-white metal that is often mixed with other metals or used to cover them to prevent them from rusting.
examples: a tin mine
a tin box
a tin roof/shack/shed

senses.definition: used to say that something is as good or effective as it claims to be, or that it really does what it claims to do. This expression is especially used when you are comparing advertisements with actual products.
examples: I paid £150 for this camera and am more than happy with it. It does exactly what it says on the tin!

senses.definition: very nervous
examples: She was like a cat on a hot tin roof before her driving test.

senses.definition: very small in size or amount
examples: a tiny baby
We come from a tiny little town in upstate New York.
Brenda felt a tiny bit bored.
Only a tiny minority hold such extreme views.
Most of the land is owned by a tiny fraction of the population.
Even a tiny amount of food may trigger an allergic reaction.
a tiny village/town/island
Look at his little tiny fingers. Aren't they cute?
The minister appealed to the Cabinet not to target her comparatively tiny budget of £4 billion.
His room is absolutely tiny.
She felt the tiniest bit annoyed.
The tiniest amount of this drug would knock out an elephant.
There's only one tiny problem with the booking.

senses.definition: a way of referring to children when somebody wants, or is going to have, a baby
examples: We can't wait to hear the patter of tiny feet.

senses.definition: a small piece of advice about something practical
examples: tip on/for doing something handy tips for buying a computer
tip on/for something useful tips on how to save money
(British English, informal) Here are my top tips for interview success.
The blog offered various beauty tips.
His money tips and tricks could save a typical family up to £6 000 a year.
Follow these tips to improve your communication skills.
I picked up some useful tips from my ski instructor.
Take a safety tip from me—get that light fixed!
Share your gardening tips with other readers.

senses.definition: a secret or expert piece of advice about what the result of a competition, etc. is likely to be, especially about which horse is likely to win a race
examples: a hot tip for the big race

senses.definition: secret information that somebody gives, for example to the police, to warn them about an illegal activity that is going to happen or has happened
examples: The man was arrested after an anonymous tip.

senses.definition: a small amount of extra money that you give to somebody, for example somebody who serves you in a restaurant
examples: to leave a tip
He gave the waiter a generous tip.
Someone put a dollar in the tip jar.
He left the waitress a large tip.
We get fewer tips on weeknights.
Are we supposed to leave a tip?

senses.definition: the thin, pointed end of something
examples: the tips of your fingers
the tip of your nose
the northern tip of the island
The cat was black except for a patch of white on the very tip of its tail.
He ran the tips of his fingers over the bruise.

senses.definition: a small part that fits on or over the end of something
examples: a walking stick with a rubber tip

senses.definition: a place where you can take rubbish and leave it
an untidy place
examples: Their flat is a tip!

senses.definition: if a word or name is on the tip of your tongue, you are sure that you know it but you cannot remember it
only a small part of a much larger problem
examples: This figure represents only the tip of the iceberg, since as many as 90% of cases go unreported.

senses.definition: to give somebody an extra amount of money to thank them for something they have done for you as part of their job
examples: Americans were always welcome because they tended to tip heavily.
tip somebody Did you remember to tip the waiter?
tip somebody something She tipped the porter a dollar.

senses.definition: to move so that one end or side is higher than the other; to move something into this position
examples: (+ adv./prep.) The boat tipped to one side.
The seat tips forward to allow passengers into the back.
tip something (+ adv./prep.) She tipped her head back and laughed loudly.
He tipped the wheelbarrow on its side.
His hat was tipped over his forehead.
While trying to sit down, I tipped the tray and my entire dinner went onto the rug.

senses.definition: to make something/somebody come out of a container or its/their position by holding or lifting it/them at an angle
examples: She tipped the dirty water down the drain.
The bus stopped abruptly, nearly tipping me out of my seat.

senses.definition: to touch something lightly so that it moves in a particular direction
examples: The goalkeeper just managed to tip the ball over the crossbar.

senses.definition: to leave rubbish somewhere outdoors in order to get rid of it
examples: ‘No tipping.’ (= for example, on a notice)

senses.definition: to say in advance that somebody/something will be successful
examples: be tipped for something The band is being tipped for the top.
The film is being hotly tipped for Oscar success.
be tipped as something The senator has been tipped by many as a future president.
She has been widely tipped as a future CEO.
be tipped to do something The actor is tipped to win an Oscar for his performance.

senses.definition: to cover the end or edge of something with a colour, a substance, etc.
examples: be tipped with something The wings are tipped with yellow.

senses.definition: used to say that you admire somebody very much for something they have done
it is/was raining heavily
to affect the result of something in one way rather than another
examples: In an interview, smart presentation can tip the scales in your favour.
New evidence tipped the balance against the prosecution.

senses.definition: to make your plans or intentions known
to weigh a particular amount
examples: He tipped the scales at just over 80 kilos.

senses.definition: to give somebody secret information that they can use to gain an advantage for themselves
examples: There’s no way he would have bought those shares if someone in the company hadn’t tipped him the wink.

senses.definition: feeling that you would like to sleep or rest; needing rest
examples: to be/look/feel tired
I'm too tired even to think.
They were cold, hungry and tired out (= very tired).
He still felt really tired and wanted to stay in bed.
tired from something I'm still a bit tired from the journey.
tired from doing something I take the bus when my legs get tired from walking.
We were both so dead tired that we kept falling asleep.
She was tired after a long day at the office.
tired feet
Of course I'm not ill. I'm just tired.
Polly suddenly felt awfully tired.
The walk left me quite tired out.
The words danced on the page before his tired eyes.

senses.definition: feeling that you have had enough of somebody/something because you no longer find them/it interesting or because they make you angry or unhappy
examples: tired of somebody/something I'm sick and tired of all the arguments.
She had grown heartily tired of his company.
tired of doing something She was tired of hearing about their trip to India.
tired of somebody doing something I'm really tired of people complaining about us.

senses.definition: boring because it is too familiar or has been used too much
examples: He always comes out with the same tired old jokes.
It's a tired cliché-ridden definition of leadership.
It's the same tired advice that was given to my mother.
The word ‘empowering’ is tired and overused.

senses.definition: the name of a book, poem, painting, piece of music, etc.
examples: What's title of her new book?
a book/album title
Some of his song titles and lyrics have also attracted criticism.
under a title His poems were published under the title of ‘Love and Reason’.
the title track from their latest CD (= the song with the same title as the disc)
She has sung the title role in ‘Carmen’ (= the role of Carmen in that opera).
The title character (= the person mentioned in the name of the book, play, etc.) is a native of Colombia.

senses.definition: a particular book or magazine
examples: The company publishes twenty new titles a year.
40% of new titles were actually new editions of existing books.
Sony has released six new game titles.

senses.definition: a word in front of a person’s name to show their rank or profession, whether or not they are married, etc.
examples: The present duke inherited the title from his father.
Give your name and title (= Mr, Miss, Ms, Dr, etc.).
My name is Maria.
His name is Tom Smith.
John T. Harvey
Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Hello, Maria.
Hello, Mr Brown.
Thank you, Doctor.
She has a title.
The king bestowed lands and titles upon his followers.
The justices are accorded the courtesy title ‘Lord’.
Count Victor Oldenburg and Hess, to give him his full title
‘Mrs’ was a courtesy title for any unmarried woman in business at that time.
‘Minister’ is one of several diplomatic titles.

senses.definition: a name that describes a job
examples: The official title of the job is ‘Administrative Assistant’.
What is your name and job title?
Bessie Smith earned the title ‘Empress of the Blues’.
In 2017, Brooks assumed the title of chairman.
She bears the grand title ‘Divisional President of the Finances Committee’.
He was given the title of ‘wise man’.

senses.definition: the position of being the winner of a competition, especially a sports competition
examples: She has won three world titles.
He'll be defending his title at this week's French Open.
the world heavyweight title
the league/division/national title
a title fight (= in boxing)
Suzuki won seven consecutive batting titles in Japan's Pacific League.
Deportivo clinched the title with a goal in the final seconds of the last game of the season.
He's a leading contender for the European title.
She's hoping to win her third Olympic title.
They won 5–1 in the final to retain the title.
He has been building up fitness for his world title challenge.

senses.definition: the legal right to own something, especially land or property; the document that shows you have this right
examples: He claims he has title to the land.

senses.definition: to give a book, piece of music, etc. a particular name
examples: be titled… Their first album was titled ‘Made in Valmez’.
an article titled ‘Is Music Dead?’
These poems are from a manuscript tentatively titled ‘The Hunter’.

senses.definition: used to show purpose or intention
examples: I set out to buy food.
I am going to tell you a story.
She was determined to do well.
His aim was to become president.
To be honest with you, I don't remember what he said.

senses.definition: used to show the result of something
examples: She managed to escape.
It was too hot to go out.
He couldn't get close enough to see.

senses.definition: used to show the cause of something
examples: I'm sorry to hear that.

senses.definition: used to show an action that you want or are advised to do
examples: I'd love to go to France this summer.
The leaflet explains how to apply for a place.
I don't know what to say.

senses.definition: used to show something that is known or reported about a particular person or thing
examples: The house was said to be haunted.

senses.definition: used to show that one action immediately follows another
examples: I reached the station only to find that my train had already left.

senses.definition: used to show that you must or should do something
examples: You are not to talk during the exam.
She was to be here at 8.30 but she didn't arrive.

senses.definition: in the direction of something; towards something
examples: I walked to the office.
It fell to the ground.
It was on the way to the station.
He's going to Paris.
my first visit to Africa
He pointed to something on the opposite bank.
Her childhood was spent travelling from place to place.

senses.definition: as far as something
examples: The meadows lead down to the river.
Her hair fell to her waist.

senses.definition: located in the direction mentioned from something
examples: Place the cursor to the left of the first word.
There are mountains to the north.

senses.definition: used to show the person or thing that receives something
examples: He gave it to his sister.
I'll explain to you where everything goes.
I am deeply grateful to my parents.
Who did she address the letter to?
(formal) To whom did she address the letter?

senses.definition: used to show the end or limit of a range or period of time
examples: a drop in profits from $105 million to around $75 million
I'd say he was 25 to 30 years old (= approximately 25 or 30 years old).
I like all kinds of music from opera to reggae.
We only work from Monday to Friday.
I watched the programme from beginning to end.

senses.definition: before the start of something
examples: How long is it to lunch?
(especially British English) It's five to ten (= five minutes before ten o'clock).

senses.definition: reaching a particular state
examples: The vegetables were cooked to perfection.
He tore the letter to pieces.
She sang the baby to sleep.
The letter reduced her to tears (= made her cry).
His expression changed from amazement to joy.

senses.definition: used to show the person or thing that is affected by an action
examples: She is devoted to her family.
What have you done to your hair?

senses.definition: used to show that two things are attached or connected
examples: Attach this rope to the front of the car.

senses.definition: used to show a relationship between one person or thing and another
examples: She's married to an Italian.
the Japanese ambassador to France
the key to the door
the solution to this problem

senses.definition: directed towards; in connection with
examples: It was a threat to world peace.
She made a reference to her recent book.

senses.definition: used to introduce the second part of a comparison or ratio
examples: I prefer walking to climbing.
The industry today is nothing to what it once was.
We won by six goals to three.

senses.definition: used to show a quantity or rate
examples: There are 2.54 centimetres to an inch.
This car does 30 miles to the gallon.

senses.definition: in honour of somebody/something
examples: a monument to the soldiers who died in the war
Let's drink to Julia and her new job.

senses.definition: used to show somebody’s attitude or reaction to something
examples: His music isn't really to my taste.
To her astonishment, he smiled.

senses.definition: used to show what somebody’s opinion or feeling about something is
examples: It sounded like crying to me.

senses.definition: while something else is happening or being done
examples: He left the stage to prolonged applause.

senses.definition: used after verbs of movement to mean ‘with the intention of giving something’
examples: People rushed to her rescue and picked her up.

senses.definition: on this day
examples: I've got a piano lesson later today.
The exams start a week today/today week (= one week from now).
The company today announced a plan that involves cutting 12% of its workforce.
A press release is due out today or tomorrow.

senses.definition: at the present period
examples: Young people today face a very difficult future at work.
Today people have greater expectations for their retirement years.
Only 9% of students today say they plan to attend a school more than 500 miles from home.

senses.definition: this day
examples: Today is her tenth birthday.
Today is Monday.
The review is in today's paper.
I'm leaving a week from today.
Today was definitely a good day!

senses.definition: the present period of time
examples: The film is about growing up in today's world.
In today's society, there is widespread concern about obesity.
The animation is poor by today's standards.
Today's announcement is great for consumers.
today’s young people
of today the youth of today

senses.definition: one of the five small parts that stick out from the foot; any similar part on the foot of an animal or bird
examples: the big/little toe (= the largest/smallest toe)
I stubbed my toe on the step.
Can you touch your toes (= by bending over while keeping your legs straight)?
She wiggled her fingers and toes thoughtfully.
on your toes She stood on her toes and kissed him.
They are ground birds with long toes and claws.
He stepped on my toe while we were dancing!
Luckily, a truck came to tow our car to safety.
Can you give us a tow to a garage?
He had some kind of fungus between his toes.
He moved lightly on his toes like a boxer.
I dipped my toe in the river to test the temperature.
I stood on the tips of my toes to look through the window.
Ouch! That was my toe you just trod on.
She stood on her toes to kiss him.
She tapped her toes to the music.
The shoe pressed painfully against her big toe.
Under his bare toes the floor felt gritty.

senses.definition: the part of a sock, shoe, etc. that covers the toes
examples: He kicked the earth with the toe of his boot.

senses.definition: having the type or number of toes mentioned
examples: open-toed sandals
a three-toed sloth

senses.definition: to refuse to do something or to change your mind about something
examples: They dug their toes in and would not lower the price.

senses.definition: to start doing something very carefully to see if it will be successful or not

senses.definition: a small detail that is added to something in order to improve it or make it complete
examples: Meeting them at the airport was a nice touch.
Bright cushions add a decorative touch to a room.
The family photos add a homely touch.
The candles gave the table a romantic touch.
The decor includes many idiosyncratic little touches.

senses.definition: a way or style of doing something
examples: She prefers to answer any fan mail herself for a more personal touch.
Computer graphics will give your presentation the professional touch.
He couldn't find his magic touch with the ball today (= he didn't play well).
This meal is awful. I think I'm losing my touch (= my ability to do something).
He found his old political touch when the crisis emerged.
He must regain his shooting touch.
She seemed to have a deft touch with comedy.
With students she had a sure touch and showed great personal sensitivity.
a politician who lacked the common touch

senses.definition: a very small amount
examples: There was a touch of sarcasm in her voice.
There could be a touch of frost tonight.
He has just the right touch of arrogance for the role.
Her speech brought a welcome touch of frivolity to the evening.
Give your garden a touch of class with a sundial as a focal point.

senses.definition: slightly; a little
examples: The music was a touch too loud for my liking.

senses.definition: the area outside the lines that mark the sides of the playing field
examples: into touch He kicked the ball into touch.

senses.definition: to not know or understand what is happening in a particular subject or area
examples: Unfortunately, the people making the decisions are out of touch with the real world.
This government is increasingly out of touch with ordinary voters.

senses.definition: to communicate with somebody, especially by writing to them or phoning them
examples: Are you still in touch with your friends from college?
Thanks for showing us your products—we'll be in touch.
I'm trying to get in touch with Jane. Do you have her number?
Let's keep in touch.
I'll put you in touch with someone in your area.
The security staff were in close touch with the local police.

senses.definition: to know what is happening in a particular subject or area
examples: It is important to keep in touch with the latest research.

senses.definition: to no longer communicate with somebody, so that you no longer know what is happening to them
examples: We’ve been out of touch for a couple of years.

senses.definition: the ability of a powerful or famous person to talk to and understand ordinary people
a person that you can easily persuade to do something, especially to give you money
examples: Unfortunately, my father is no soft touch.

senses.definition: to reject something or treat it as not important; to stop dealing with a problem
examples: He tends to deal with disputes by kicking them into the long grass.

senses.definition: the ability to deal with something in a sensitive and relaxed way
examples: She handles this difficult subject with a light touch.

senses.definition: to no longer have any contact with somebody/something
examples: I've lost touch with all my old friends.

senses.definition: to no longer understand something, especially how ordinary people feel
to put your hand or another part of your body onto somebody/something
examples: Don't touch that plate—it's hot!
Can you touch your toes? (= bend and reach them with your hands)
touch somebody on something I touched him lightly on the arm.
touch somebody/something with something Do not touch anything with your bare hands.
He has hardly touched the ball all game.
(figurative) I must do some more work on that article—I haven't touched it all week.
Don't you dare touch me!
He accidentally touched a live wire attached to overhead power cables.
He did not actually touch the substance, but may have inhaled it.
He was close enough to touch her.
He wouldn't let me touch the wound.
Her hand reached out to touch his cheek.
His fingers briefly touched hers.
She hugged him, being careful not to touch his broken wrist.
In social groups, dolphins often touch each other with their pectoral fins.

senses.definition: to be or come so close together that there is no space between
examples: Make sure the wires don't touch.
Their faces were almost touching.
touch something Don't let your coat touch the wet paint.
His coat was so long it was almost touching the floor.
The dancer’s feet hardly seemed to touch the ground.

senses.definition: to move something, especially in such a way that you damage it; to hit or harm somebody
examples: I told you not to touch my things.
He said I kicked him, but I never touched him!

senses.definition: to make somebody feel upset or emotional
examples: touch somebody/something Her story touched us all deeply.
What he said really touched my heart.
I had been touched by his kindness to my aunts.
touch somebody/something to do something It truly touches me to know that I am holding in my hand a piece of paper used by someone who lived in 1745.

senses.definition: to affect somebody/something
examples: These are issues that touch us all.
The life of a shepherd has been only marginally touched by technological change.
Even the most remote areas are now directly touched by political, educational and medical advances.

senses.definition: to eat, drink or use something
examples: You've hardly touched your food.
He hasn't touched the money his aunt left him.

senses.definition: to be as good as somebody in skill, quality, etc.
examples: No one can touch him when it comes to interior design.

senses.definition: to reach a particular level, etc.
examples: The speedometer was touching 90.

senses.definition: to become connected with or work with a situation or person
examples: Everything she touches turns to disaster.
His last two movies have been complete flops and now no studio will touch him.

senses.definition: to be seen on somebody’s face for a short time
examples: A smile touched the corners of his mouth.

senses.definition: to have a small amount of a particular quality
examples: His hair was touched with grey.
Some of her poems are touched with real genius.

senses.definition: to upset somebody by reminding them of something they are particularly sensitive about
to mention a subject that makes somebody feel angry, upset, embarrassed, etc.
examples: You touched a raw nerve when you mentioned his first wife.
My remarks about divorce had unwittingly touched a raw nerve.
The article struck a raw nerve as it revived unpleasant memories.

senses.definition: to not hurt somebody physically in any way
to refuse to get involved with somebody/something or in a particular situation
examples: Personally, I wouldn’t touch him or his business with a bargepole.

senses.definition: to say or do something that makes people feel sympathy or enthusiasm
examples: The speaker had obviously struck a chord with his audience.

senses.definition: to make contact with somebody again
to reach the ground at the bottom of an area of water
examples: I put my feet down and touched bottom.

senses.definition: to reach the worst possible state or condition
examples: Her career really touched bottom with that movie.

senses.definition: to say or do something that makes people feel sympathy or enthusiasm
examples: The speaker had obviously touched a chord with his audience.

senses.definition: to show too much respect for somebody of a higher class, especially because you are anxious about what they think of you
used when talking about your previous good luck or your hopes for the future, to avoid bringing bad luck
examples: I've been driving for over 20 years and never had an accident—touch wood!

senses.definition: very close
examples: We came within touching distance of winning the cup.
We live within spitting distance of the bus station.

senses.definition: having or causing problems or difficulties
examples: a tough childhood
It was a tough decision to make.
During the interview I was asked some really tough questions.
Now Karen must make one of the toughest choices of her life.
She's been having a tough time of it (= a lot of problems) lately.

What was the toughest job you ever had?
a tough task
It can be tough trying to juggle a career and a family.

tough on somebody Puberty can be tough on kids.
I knew she was going to be tough to beat.
He may find it tough to pursue his plans.

Things were pretty tough at first.
It's tough out there in the real world.
The next couple of months will be tough, but I'm sure we'll cope.

senses.definition: demanding that particular rules be obeyed and showing a lack of sympathy for any problems that this may cause
examples: tough with somebody/something It's about time teachers started to get tough with bullies.
tough on somebody/something Politicians believe they have to be tough on crime.
Don't be too tough on him—he was only trying to help.
The school takes a tough line on (= punishes severely) cheating.

tough new anti-terror measures

senses.definition: strong enough to deal successfully with difficult conditions or situations
examples: a tough breed of cattle

She’s a tough cookie/customer (= somebody who knows what they want and is not easily influenced by other people).

senses.definition: physically strong and likely to be violent
examples: You think you're so tough, don't you?
He plays the tough guy in the movie.
Then this guy started acting tough.

senses.definition: with a lot of crime or violence
examples: She grew up in a tough neighbourhood.

senses.definition: difficult to cut or bite on
examples: The meat was a bit tough.
Overcooking the burger will make it tough and dry.

senses.definition: not easily cut, broken, torn, etc.
examples: a tough pair of shoes
The reptile's skin is tough and scaly.

senses.definition: unlucky for somebody in a way that seems unfair
examples: It was tough on her being dropped from the team like that.
(ironic) ‘I can't get it finished in time.’ ‘Tough! (= I don't feel sorry about it.)’

senses.definition: to be determined and refuse to change your attitude or ideas
a person who is difficult to deal with or to influence
a difficult problem or situation to deal with
a person or event that is so good or successful at something that it will be difficult for anyone/anything else coming after them to be as good or successful
examples: She has been an excellent principal and will be a hard act to follow.
Their contribution will prove a tough act to follow.

senses.definition: to tell people very strongly what you want
very strong and able to deal successfully with difficult conditions or situations
examples: She’s almost 90 but she’s still as tough as old boots.

senses.definition: used to show sympathy for somebody that something bad that has happened to
examples: ‘I failed by one point.’ ‘That's tough luck.’

senses.definition: used to show that you do not feel sorry for somebody who has a problem
examples: ‘If you take the car, I won't be able to go out.’ ‘Tough luck!’

senses.definition: when conditions or progress become difficult (strong and determined people work even harder to succeed)
a journey made for pleasure during which several different towns, countries, etc. are visited
examples: a walking/sightseeing/bus tour
tour of/round/around something a coach tour of northern France

a tour operator (= a person or company that organizes tours)
a business trip
a five-minute trip by taxi
a long and difficult journey across the mountains
a tour of Bavaria
the first expedition to the South Pole

senses.definition: an act of walking around a town, building, etc. in order to visit it

a virtual tour (= shown on a computer) of the Taj Mahal
a tour of inspection (= an official visit of a factory, classroom, etc. made by somebody whose job is to check that everything is working as expected)
a tour guide
tour of/round/around something Our host gave us a quick tour of the house.

senses.definition: a series of competitions organized for professional players

senses.definition: a period of time when somebody is serving in the military or as a diplomat in a particular place

senses.definition: to travel around a place, for example on holiday, or to perform, to advertise something, etc.

senses.definition: a member of a sports team that is playing a series of official games in a foreign country
in the direction of somebody/something
examples: They were heading towards the German border.

senses.definition: getting closer to achieving something

senses.definition: close or closer to a point in time

senses.definition: in relation to somebody/something

senses.definition: with the aim of obtaining something, or helping somebody to obtain something

senses.definition: a piece of cloth or paper used for drying things, especially your body

a beach towel (= a large towel used for lying on in the sun)

senses.definition: to throw a towel into the ring as a sign that you admit that you have been defeated

senses.definition: a tall structure used for sending television or radio signals

senses.definition: a tall piece of furniture used for storing things

senses.definition: a person that you can rely on to help, protect and comfort you when you are in trouble

senses.definition: the people who live in a particular town

senses.definition: to do something with a lot of energy, enthusiasm, etc., especially by spending a lot of money

senses.definition: a man who frequently goes to fashionable parties, clubs, theatres, etc.

senses.definition: the most important thing of a particular type, or the only thing that is available

made as a copy of a particular thing and used for playing with

senses.definition: of a very small type

a single track road (= wide enough for only one vehicle) with passing places

senses.definition: the sport of running on a track

senses.definition: a rough path or road, usually one that has not been built but that has been made by people walking there
